reviewText:
[SUMMARY]

For a game that is free to play, and has very little download time it is most certainly worth your time, if you got 30 minutes or so spare, download this game and play it. Do note if you are under the age of 13, that you need to think carefully before playing this game, because it might scare younger players, but to be honest do feel free to play it, and finish it. Totally recommend: 8/10.

[IN DEPTH REVIEW]

So, you still have your doubts huh? Well, I’ll explain why it is so great.

The storyline is so brilliant for an indie horror game, to be honest I hate horror games, but this, was something I actually enjoyed, it has no jump scares (although I did rush the game for the review, I may update it later if there is one, that I may have missed during rushing), and is purely driven about the idea of psychological horror, and that’s what makes it such a compelling storyline, and, despite the multiple chills I felt going down my back, I continued, because I wanted to see what would happen, and how it would end.

In terms of playability, it is, like most indie games, a pick up and play, the only thing that will make you think, is the complexity of the situation, and not which controls you need to press, the themes of this game is mildly concerning, (not going to spoil anything) and at the end, really makes you think about yourself, and if what your doing is right. I really struggled to get started on this review, purely because it keep returning to my mind, but, that is what the game is meant to do to you.

The game itself is quite a lot more serious than the clone of games being released every 3 weeks (*cough* Five Nights at Freddy’s *cough*), and is a ton better than whatever they are releasing, so before spending some of your hard earned cash, (or not so hard earned cash, I don’t know how you get money), why not give this a whirl first? Truth to be told, it has more entertainment value than You-Know-What.

My only complaint about the game would be that the game really could and should have been a great deal longer, the story and plot line has so much room for expansion, don’t get me wrong this game is good as it is, but an update or something to have more of a capitalisation upon the story of the characters (trying not to spoil here), as it was not really explained enough to really give to effective of a cliff-hanger, but is suppose, it is about the psychological effects more than the plot after all.

Addressing re-playability,  it looks the game that you might feel inclined to play and then play again immediately, or after a few weeks of intervals, because the story immerses you so well, (like I said room for expansion) that you really want to replay it, (after this review I’m probably going off to replay it, because it’s so good), but, to be honest, it doesn’t need to be replayed, however, if you got the time, replay it, because it’s like your looking through a completely different perspective, and maybe I would of get FNAF 2 if I had the ability to be the animatronics, but to be honest, it isn’t up my street anyway, (I hate jump scares, poorest way of adding tension, but I’m not a game developer, so what do I know?), but I’m getting off topic.

Next on my list is the graphics, and when I say what you expected from a game that takes barely any time to download, your answer would probably be not much, however, this graphics, enhances the game, and makes it more immersive, it feels older, making you feel it is more unknown the games you normally play, and considering the engine used was Unity free version, you can count me impressed. I think the creator could not be more right with this “It features a unique artstyle that combines elements of pixel horror with realistic lighting effect, which is intended to enhance the surreal atmosphere”. That right there is exactly what it does, the graphic make it feel more real, it makes the atmosphere feel as if it is happening with just you in control of the body, and that the body you control, is you, and you want to know who is this character, and what is he/she doing here? What relevance does it have to the story? How does the title fit in with all this? And that is exactly why you play this game past the opening moments, because you want to know the answer, and you are going to play through this game multiple times just to find out what is going on here. And that is the true beauty of an indie game like this.

Last, but most certainly not least, the music. This tune, fits too well for this game, the eerie sound of the tune fits in perfectly with the game itself, as if the music was made specifically for the game (maybe it was?) because it naturally makes sense for the sounds being played and the game itself, I can’t have any real complaints about this game, because, on all aspects, its indie developer’s dream, because it doesn’t appear to have any bugs, its well-made and fluid.

I really want to say how impressed I am by this, and I give kudos to the creator for such a unique and enjoyable game, that has changed my opinion on all horror games, and the genre itself, maybe I might get those games with lots of zombies and jump scares in it… No. This game is beautifully original, and is hand crafted to a perfect game, and is an absolute gem.

If you’re still not willing to give this game a go, then… I don’t know, maybe you just don’t like psychological horror, or maybe you’re on your phone or something, and you can’t download it yet, who knows, maybe you’re holidaying in Belarus, and won’t be back for a while.

So, in a nutshell, good game, well played. Sorry for any mistakes, I’m not fluent English, if you have any questions, or want me to review a game, add me or drop a comment on this, or my profile.
And on that bombshell…

Goodnight!

P.S: I do know this game has been out since March last year, but just wasn’t on Steam

reviewText:
Fingerbones is the first horror game by David Szymanski, the creative mind that brought us such gems as The Moon Sliver and The Music Machine. Originally published in 2013, the game wound up on Steam around a year later. This title is a short exploratory horror mixed with narration in the way of journal pages scattered about. It's up to you to unravel the dark story within, by solving a simple series of puzzles.

I would be lying if I said that Fingerbones didn't keep me looking over my in-game shoulder, amidst the eerie crying of a child and dense fog. I was almost certain that I would see some demon-spawn in kid form awaiting me around the next corner, or behind a door. Needless to say, the thick and immersive atmosphere, however simplistic it may be, really sucks you in during the short timeframe of this narrative story. From the stand-alone mechanical howling of the generator in a well lit top level, to the forlorn cries of a child and creepy silence of the basement, every moment is suspenseful in some way.

The game uses Minecraft-like textures, in that everything is heavily and purposefully pixelated. Usually this distracts from any horror element that a game may have, turning them into child friendly PG-13 types. Thankfully, that is not the case here; however brief it may be, the chilling story is enough to send a shiver down the spine of any adult. The game only lasts 15-30 minutes at best, and there are only a handful of journal pages scattered about; it would've been nice if there was more story to this narrative-centric experience.

For a short and free horror title, Fingerbones is one of the best that you'll come across. Prepare to white-knuckle your mouse for the next half hour of entertainment, while anxiously waiting for what may be around the next bend. Take your time, don't rush, and read the pages carefully to fully understand what unimaginable horrors that this poor excuse of a father put his child through. Then, if you enjoyed yourself, go ahead and take a look at the other games from this fantastic developer.

reviewText:
Fingerbones is the next title from the same developer as The Moon Sliver, but will you want to play this ?

In Fingerbones we play as a man that walks around a basement and tries to relive past memories ( I will not go into further detail for the plot because that would spoil the entire game).

Gameplay is simple. All you do is walk around and pick up notes and solve a couple of puzzles. It's really simple stuff, but if you do play the game it will be for the story.

Graphics are simple pixel horror style, but use different lighting effects which gives the game a really awesome look.  Now some of the item models look a bit weird it's still a really good looking game.

Audio is fantastic. The audio will make you feel like you're not alone and it's just really well done. The music is really good to, but there's not much of it.

The game has really simple level design so I doubt anyone would get stuck in this game. There's not much more to say about it.

The game is really short. It took me 15 minutes to finish the entire thing and I loved every second of it. Apart from the one playthrough you will do there's not much replay value.

I didn't encounter any bugs what so ever. The game ran smoothly and I highly doubt that anyone would have problems playing it.

Overall Fingerbones is a really good indie horror game. Now I wouldn't say it's better than Moon Sliver, but it's still really good. I highly suggest playing through it at least once. I give Fingerbones a 8/10

I played this game the first time, and finished it feeling like something was missing. I felt like it didn't quite drive the point home enough for me, or leave me with a sense of horror afterwards. So I played it again. And I feel I got more out of the experience this time, but still, I feel that it's missing something. It's all there in the notes, and the story is well layed out (and quite gruesome, don't get me wrong), but I feel like the game didn't quite go all the way for me. However, I do recommend this game because it looks great stylistically, the story is well written, and while the horror (for whatever reason) didn't quite hit me as hard as I would have liked, it is a sufficiently atmospheric and creepy game that tells a pretty diabolical story. Perhaps this game will hit others where it didn't hit me.

reviewText: Fingerbones is abstract and narrative-driven. It focuses on the events taking place in the life of a husband and father that has lived through an apocalyptic event and the personal philosophies that drive him after the fact. The puzzle mechanics are very simple (looking around your environment for clues that hint at passwords to open doors) and exist to expand on his narrative as he goes. It's very short, but filled with a subtle sense of dread as the story unfolds and you get a better idea as to what's going on in his head. If you like psychological horror and philosphies on the nature of morality, rationality and society, you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
Beautiful...Just beautiful.


This is exactly the type of videogame i have been looking for since 2012, after the release of the FANTASTIC psychological shooter Spec Ops : The Line.


Fingerbones is a different type of horror game. It isn't a horror game that uses cheap jumpscares to frighten you
Instead, Fingerbones uses your mind through different notes scattered around an environment that you need to read to uncover the secrets of the place you're in. At the beggining, you don't know who you are, where you are or what your purpose is. After reading every single note, uncovering every secret of this AMAZING but at the same time HORRIFIC
story, you finally find out who you are and what your purpose was from the beggining.


The game's main enemy is found right at the end, and this enemy will surprise you the same way as it surprised me.


The horrific story of the game somehow resembles I Am Legend combined with a Friday the 13th movie, although it's very original and the core is just a very tiny bit alike these 2 masterpieces.


Fingerbones can be finished in about 20-30 minutes, and uses no savegames.

Overall, all i can say is congratulations to the developer for creating this masterpiece. We need more games like these, games that make us think and eventually ♥♥♥♥ with our minds in both a good and a clever way.

I definitely recommend this game, and it definitely made it into my Gaming Hall of Fame

I rate it 10/10


BEWARE: IF YOU ARE NOT USED TO HORROR GAMES DO NOT PLAY THIS GAME, THE ATMOSPHERE, MUSIC AND GENERAL STORY ARE NOT FOR THE EASILY SCARED! YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED

Review	It's a short atmospheric puzzle-horror game (no jump scares) that lasts about 30 minutes on your first try.

You start out in a room with no information on who you are and how you got there. As you start reading the notes scattered around the building you learn piece by piece of what happened. The only game play here is walking around and pushing the left mouse button. Once you've found all the clues the game will end and ultimately you have to decide what happened.

A nice little thriller/psychological horror game that focuses on the core value of horror - the atmosphere.

During the game, nothing too significant happens but the way it builds up tension and suspense is quite remarkable. I also liked the way the puzzles link with the story of the game and the graphics (they're actually really well suited to the style of the game!).

The ending was also good with a small twist to it. Some of the sounds gave me a slight shiver too which I think ties in with the fantastic atmosphere this game has to offer.

If you're looking for something long winded and jumpscarish, don't waste your time with this game. However, if you're a fan of indie games, horror, and not things screaming in the face of the player, I really would recommend it!

9/10

So he and his daughter ran into the bunker, and he must've gotten cabin fever or something because what he did was not normal. Like the apocalypse, the game doesn't tell you exactly what happened, but it tells you enough to know that it was seriously messed up.  Definitely check this out. The graphics are nice, the story is obviously the main focus of the game, and the music and sound effects were perfect.

I'm going to do my best to dance around certain details of the story here so as not to spoil it for anybody, but I may have to ruin some of the gameplay surprise a little bit in order to address what I did and didn't like about the game.

It's difficult to really explain this without just fully divulging everything about it, which is largely due to it's short play time and small play area, but also because it's essentially so one-note in what it does. It doesn't faff about with superfluous information or character/world building, but instead pretty much aims straight for its intended target and fires, paying little attention to anything else around it. In this particular instance this really didn't bother me. We're pretty much given all we need to know about the situation and the people involved in the tale, both directly and indirectly, and kept on point with the story the developer wants to tell. Directly, you'll be playing as a man wandering around a... room (the nature of the environment is eventually revealed and is best discovered by the player, but at first it appears as a relatively non-descript living area with scattered furniture, boxes and notes). Indirectly, you'll be learning about the people closest to him and the roles being played by both the people and place.

Gameplay consists of reading notes that fill in the details while you sniff around the dwelling and occasionally flick switches or enter codes on a keyboard to gain access to certain things. Unless you immediately walk out the door behind your starting point, it should take you no more than 20 to 30 minutes to finish and has little real incentive to revisit, unless you just want to breathe in the incredibly unsettling atmosphere so masterfully constructed here. With the intentionally low res, pixelly art direction mixed with its effective lighting and chilling audio, it had me on edge for the entire duration of my time with it. That's easily the best thing about the game. The worst thing is, well... I hate to say it, but... pretty much everything else.

The problem I had with it is, after all that work spent crafting a tone and having the player right in the palm of your hand; being able to make their skin crawl and constantly have them looking over their shoulder, it just never actually does anything with it... nothing actually happens. The store page description does state there are no jump scares and it's more about psychological horror rather than something more manifestly horrific, but I was at least expecting some kind of pay-off to everything, for there to be an actual event to speak of, but there's no such thing here. It was a real disappointment, and more than anything, such a waste as well.

I may be mixing up my quotes here, but I think Hitchcock used to describe the tension in his movies and its effect on his audience as being like blowing up a balloon. It keeps building up more and more, bigger and bigger, and with it, the audience's expectation. But you can't keep doing that without end, there has to be a release for that tension, a pop or a bang to finally get it out of your system and kill any sense of expectation, only then can you begin to build it back up again. The problem here is there's no bang, it just... ends. Right at the final moment when you expect a big reveal or something of consequence, be it an event or some information, it merely fades to black and the game closes. There's no sense of closure to proceedings and as a result I was left feeling pretty empty and unsatisfied by the time it ended, having no release for all that built up tension and anxiety it worked so hard to create. To its credit, it at least didn't resort to cheap scares or have any silly plot twist or ineffective monster, but then, it didn't really have anything else, either.

I wish there was a Neutral verdict to click on for these reviews, and I'm so close to wanting to hit No instead, but given that it's free, it's competently constructed, is bold enough to approach some disturbing themes that are rarely ever tackled in other games (a lot of praise has to go to that especially), and the fact that it's the developer's first release (described in his own words as an experiment), I'm inclined to think it deserves a little more leeway than most. Plus, as much of a let down as it was, it still isn't actually bad at all. David Szymanski very much seems like one to watch, though, and I'll definitely be playing his other releases sometime too as they all look promising and other reviews for them seem reassuringly encouraging, but for this, at least, it's a semi successful attempt that holds lots of potential but sadly fails to truly capitalise on it.

Why didn't I enjoy playing Fingerbones?
1) Walking is much too slow. Yeah, I know at the end it makes sense since the dude is starving. This is a pain in the ♥♥♥ especially since you have to go back to the keyboard all the time.
2) I didn't find the flashlight but was able to use it later on anyway.
3) I was able to guess the last password that opens the latch to the cellar just from finding the note on the chair in the second room. I didn't even mean to be a smartass, I just thought this was the way the game wanted me to solve the second puzzle. Some might argue this contributes to the concept of a free world, but it pretty much made me miss the whole plot (I read a walkthrough later making me realize I this.) so it has to be be considered a huge design flaw. The game tells a linear story that can't be altered. Being able to take a shortcut makes one miss out on the story. That's not a good thing. Why isn't the game designed in a way that makes (accidentally) taking a shortcut impossible? Two soluitons to my problem just off the top of my head: Cellar latch isn't in the second room or can't be opened until the last page is found.
4) Just from the items on the table in the middle of the first room it was pretty easy to guess the guy physically abused and killed his daughter for reasons of insanity.
5) The story itself (even without missing most of it) is pretty dull: Guy comes back to his bunker where he and his daughter seemingly survived some kind of catastrophe that wiped out most of humanity. He rediscovers the story of their life in the bunker by reading notes, seemingly from a diary. (Why didn't he remember his story anyway? How did he forget his passwords? Playing as someone else investigating what happened there would have made much more sense.) This story reveals he has/had some kind of mental disorder (identified as depression by the game. Not being an expert on psychopathology I would rather guess something in the spectrum of Schizophrenia.) making him think it would be a good idea to act purely practical, develop strange egocentric, pseudophilosophic and nihilistic views and let out his anger, frustration and sexual urges on his daughter. The exact storyline is a little blurry: Either a) his daughter dies from the abuse and he completely loses it thinking to abolish human nature and reestablishing some sort of primitive law of survival means freedom (extremely typical 2deep4u-♥♥♥♥), or b) he looses it and then kills his daughter because he abolished humanity and needs to let out his anger/sexual frustration. Oh yeah, also he was afraid of his daughter eating his food. Another good reason to kill her. Maybe he also ate her? No, we learn from the last page we find that he threw her body in the woods. Shouldn't he have eaten her since he abolished humanity long ago? Not so practical afterall, huh? Anyway, he kept her fingerbones as a symbol of sorts to his liberation. (Why those? Makes no sense? Yeah, but who cares!)
At some point after that he got out of his bunker, survived a little, felt the need to return, got controlled by the player and upon dying in the cellar of his bunker, right next to where his daughter died, despite still hearing her screams found a feeling of freedom and peace (2deep4u again). If I missed or misinterpreted any of the story please feel free to comment and tell me so.
6) The riddles were ridiculous. Just finding all the notes and reading them is enough. I understand they're the game's way of forcingguiding one through the story, but just making them that easy is a great waste of potential. The concept also fails as stated in 3).

I was happy there weren't any jumpscares though. Thanks a lot for that. Even though I got screamed at by the guy's daughter a little (ambient noise) I'm happy the designer didn't take that road trying to enhance his game by putting in random shockers. Working with suspense is often better than giving away too much.

Fingerbones is a free to play Walking Simulator about a scientist faced with the end of humanity as he knows it. I decided to play this game because i am a writer and thought i might try getting into more horror games for the sake of one of my current writing projects (which is horror-based). Fingerbones, i'm happy to say didn't dissapoint.

While the game is short and probably meant to be completed in 10 minutes or so, i spent an hour eating up the scenery. While basic and somewhat reminicent of Minecraft, the graphics formed a very good atmosphere. It's dark and mysterious and somewhat run down. The lighting in the rooms was also brilliant. The sunset you see as soon as you start the game up is GORGEOUS and i haven't seen many horror games that greet you with something as simple yet beautiful as a sunset. So that was a nice change... The gameplay over all is pretty mucha  walking simulator (or in this case, a back-tracking simulator) as you'll be going back and fourth to a small computer (well, technically just a keyboard) to type in code words to advance in the game. And by advance, i mean more just going into other rooms... Granted, as a writer i understand why some games are made and this developer was trying their hand at creating a narrative driven game, which i totally don't mind. I love games with story. For a first attempt at a narrative-driven game i wasn't really dissapointed. From a writer's perspective i noticed some flubs here and there but there is a lot worse fiction out there and the writing here fit the atmoshpere. The game itself also has a few tropes associtated with a first attempt to have a narrative-driven game (such as only using notes or text to convey the story, waking up in a mysterious abandoned location, ect), but i didn't mind that much because it was the dev's first try and I came for the horror elements of the story.

The character the player takes on is a scientist who has witnessed what he believes is the end of humanity and he has woken up in a bunker and through scattered notes do we the player find out more about the story. The notes are all we get in terms of story so they're all we have to go on to get an idea of the setting and the character we're playing as. Through the notes we find out he has a daughter who he had custody of when everything came crashing down and i won't spoil what happens from there... This character we play as is interesting, from both a scientific and writing perspective, it's not a character we see very often. He is deeply involved in science and is devoted to his work, he can admit that maybe having a child wasn't the best decision in his life and seems geuniely unsure of how to take care of his daughter during this disaster. We usually see a character like this as a villian rather than a main character, so that's a nice change. We're delving into the thought process and mental state of someone who only knows of science and can't really think outside of that structure.

Overall, this game is supposed to be surreal horror in it's narative. Honestly, i like it :) It's my kind of horror, like something you'd see in a foreign horror film. American horror films try to scare you with an antagonist or a monster, but foreign horror films (like ones from Asia) try to get you invested in the atmosphere and the goal isn't always trying to scare you, but more to get you into the story and narrative. The game (as short as it is) kept me thinking the whole way through and though it's not scary in the typical sence (you won't be seeing any Five Nights at Freddy's style jumpscares here), it got me to care and feel somewhat afraid for this scientist and his daughter. It was more the atmosphere that scared you, the sound of a girl crying in the distance, the ambient humming of a generator and a beep from a keyboard, finding the titular fingerbones hidden away...

As a lover of games with story, the only bad thing i have to say about the game is that it does become more of a back-tracking simulator very fast. You're constantly going back to the keyboard on the first floor to type in code words to advance and go to different locations. But the game was always intended to be about narrative and completed in one sitting, so i could easily let this slide.

In conclusion this was a short little narrative driven horror game which was FREE to play. I'm happy to say i really like it despite some of it's flaws and i'd be happy to see a fuller version of the story (maybe with a bigger map to play with). Good job dev, i give Fingerbones 4 fingerbones out of 5! AND THANK YOU FOR MAKING IT FREE!

A good horror game is sometimes incredibly short, and that's not a bad thing - this visually simple, eerie little game is well worth a playthrough.  This isn't the horror that jumps out at you, it's the horror that creeps along the back of your brain and slams a nasty realization into your thoughts when you raid the fridge in the middle of the night.\n\nCheck it out.

Granted, you get what you pay for. But this game has a weak story.

[Spoilers ahead]

The protagonist writes diatribes of generic ideology of the disaffected, disparages emotion in favor of reason, and fails to see his ex-wife and daughter as human beings. Okay, but this has really been done before.

Another story about a man who kills a woman. Correction, incestuously rapes his daughter then kills her. What if the story was from Katie’s perspective? What if it was about her struggle with an emotionally and morally empty father? What if it didn’t end in her murder? Was there any way for her to triumph? This would have been far scarier as a story if the protagonist was trapped in a bunker with an attacker and had to survive, and furthermore, would have been a more fully developed concept as a story.

Was human society really destroyed, or was this an excuse to kidnap Katie? I can’t tell. Maybe other players understood this fully. If the father left the bunker and returned, where did leave to if civilization was destroyed? This could be an interesting question for the player to think about, but in order to say “yes, the writers cause us to ask this question purposefully”, they would have had to confirm if civilization was actually destroyed or if it was a delusion. Why are there windows on a bunker? Or was the cellar technically the bunker?

Why did the father return to the bunker to read his own notes? I understand it is for the purpose of enabling the central concept of the game, but it doesn’t make that much sense as a character motivation. Perhaps if he had returned for the fingers, the souvenir of his kill, it could have made more sense. And why does he just lay down and die at the end? Most people don’t just lay down and die. And the reader suddenly getting a third person narrative telling them the father laid down and died seems sloppy. There are methods of storytelling that could show the reader this. Is the father’s laying down and dying supposed to be an expression of remorse? If so, how did he get to a place where he could even feel remorse? That would be a good story to tell about his character.

I understand the developers were going for a Hitchcock-style ending that made the player go, Oh! I was playing the killer all along!"

But let's focus on the plot, which is the true center of this game:


First of all, the themes of Fingerbones are not easy. I don't want to spoiler anything, but if you are a very sensible person, maybe this is not the game for you.
And I don't mean there are gory or terrifying jumpscares, but the story itself can be very disturbing.
The horror element is build only on the psychological level, and the only 'true' scares in Fingerbones are some sounds.

This kind of horror build-up is what I truly like in Fingerbones, since there are very few games that have managed to do that so well.
The anxiety is created as you read the notes and discover the terrible story of the protagonist and the place where you are, and the horror (or disgust) as you realize what has appened.

But, in my opinion, this is also the main flaw of this game: the focus on the story make it a bit sterile.
There is the story, and nothing else, and the plot itself is not completely explored as it deserves.

In the end, Fingerbones is not a bad game, and in many ways it succeeded where others have failed, but, it leaves the feeling that there is something missing, and the story could have been explained and expanded better

reviewText: Fingerbones is less of a game, and more of an interactive horror story. It's a damn good one, too. Only one playthrough is necessary for this half-hour-or-less trip into the darkest parts of the human mind. And it's all you're going to want after you've finished.\n\nThe horror in Fingerbones is mostly quiet. There are no monsters. There are no graphic images. Everything is left to your imagination. And that's why it works.
Sometimes it takes a minute to catch on. Otherwise, great atmosphere in the game, pretty creepy stuff.

It may be short but Fingerbones leaves a strong, emotional impact on you after it's all over. With the game being free, that's enough to warrant a recommendation in my opinion.

There's not much to talk about with the gameplay. It's just WASD (move around) and interact with objects with the click of a mouse. (Not significantly different from Serena, another free short game.) This game is about exploration and reading scattered texts to unravel a dark mystery as well as learning about the former, celler-inhabitant's psyche. The only true game elements are the clues you must gather and decipher to unlock the doors and progress.

No monsters and no cheap jump scares exist to startle you. Fingerbones scares you on a deeper level in both your heart and your head. I personally found it so disturbing because the story felt so human...and so real. And this kind of horror, that which echos with reality, tends to stick with you long after.

With that said, I'm not going to pretend this is a masterpiece. It's only 20 minutes long and perhaps it could've been something grand with more time, development and depth. But as short as it was, I truly think the the developer did a sastisfying job with it.

Note: to get the most out of this short game, you must fully read the texts. Don't just skim for clues.

Fingerbones is a short yet very interesting experience. You can complete it in about 30 minutes without using a walkthrough, as the few puzzles aren't too difficult to overcome, and in my opinion this is a plus; you see it, you download it, and you play through it in barely an hour. This is the kind of games that benefit from its short length, in many different ways.

I will do my absolute best not to spoil anything in this review as it is much better to see the story unravel before you. The game takes place in what seems like a basement. You are given no apparent goal, but the game is quite clear on what you should do next, as the area you are in is quite small. The story is narrated through notes laying around, written by someone you may assume as the player character. Storytelling through notes is something that I don't particularly enjoy in video games, but it is quite well handled here.

The atmosphere is on point. The game takes advantage of its limited map to reinforce the claustrophobic impression it's creating. The visuals are great, it is dark, foggy, with a bit of light shining through the windows and that's it. The sound design is just as great. The horror is also different from what we are used to see (there are no jumpscares at all, if that kind of thing bugs you); I have not played the game Gone Home, but from what I have read of it it is rather similar; obviously, something has happened, but you don't know exactly what or who did it, and the tension builds up continually as you go further down the rabbit hole despite thinking you may not want to actually find out.

tl;dr version: Fingerbones is a short, intense and bone-chilling experience that is definitely worth your time.

Yet another quick game with a quick review. Fingerbones is an indie exploration, psychological horror game from David Szymanski. Let’s get rocking.

The Good

Like my previously reviewed game (Port of Call), Fingerbones is completely free of charge. This alone should make anyone interested in playing it.

The graphics are very much Minecraft-clone quality, but, they have a certain, eerie feel to them that really do it for Fingerbones.

The story is pretty dark. There are no jump scares here; only notes left in an abandoned bunker for you to read an reveal the story at your own pace.

The music added to the creepy atmosphere of the game. This is always a major bonus as far as immersion goes.

The Bad

Nothing to see here. Move along please.

The Meh

Some of the puzzles (yes, there are some light pseudo-puzzles you’ll be solving) require a little bit of back and forth. I wished there had been an option to move just a bit faster for this reason.

Verdict: Yea

Fingerbones is a spooky enough game that I’d recommend it for anyone looking for a quick, light scare. It is great for the Halloween season and, if you’ve been looking for something new, Fingerbones is sure to keep you occupied for a few minutes. As always, thanks for reading.

Why didn't I enjoy playing Fingerbones?
1) Walking is much too slow. Yeah, I know at the end it makes sense since the dude is starving. This is a pain in the ♥♥♥ especially since you have to go back to the keyboard all the time.
2) I didn't find the flashlight but was able to use it later on anyway.
3) I was able to guess the last password that opens the latch to the cellar just from finding the note on the chair in the second room. I didn't even mean to be a smartass, I just thought this was the way the game wanted me to solve the second puzzle. Some might argue this contributes to the concept of a free world, but it pretty much made me miss the whole plot (I read a walkthrough later making me realize I this.) so it has to be be considered a huge design flaw. The game tells a linear story that can't be altered. Being able to take a shortcut makes one miss out on the story. That's not a good thing. Why isn't the game designed in a way that makes (accidentally) taking a shortcut impossible? Two soluitons to my problem just off the top of my head: Cellar latch isn't in the second room or can't be opened until the last page is found.
4) Just from the items on the table in the middle of the first room it was pretty easy to guess the guy physically abused and killed his daughter for reasons of insanity.
5) The story itself (even without missing most of it) is pretty dull: Guy comes back to his bunker where he and his daughter seemingly survived some kind of catastrophe that wiped out most of humanity. He rediscovers the story of their life in the bunker by reading notes, seemingly from a diary. (Why didn't he remember his story anyway? How did he forget his passwords? Playing as someone else investigating what happened there would have made much more sense.) This story reveals he has/had some kind of mental disorder (identified as depression by the game. Not being an expert on psychopathology I would rather guess something in the spectrum of Schizophrenia.) making him think it would be a good idea to act purely practical, develop strange egocentric, pseudophilosophic and nihilistic views and let out his anger, frustration and sexual urges on his daughter. The exact storyline is a little blurry: Either a) his daughter dies from the abuse and he completely loses it thinking to abolish human nature and reestablishing some sort of primitive law of survival means freedom (extremely typical 2deep4u-♥♥♥♥), or b) he looses it and then kills his daughter because he abolished humanity and needs to let out his anger/sexual frustration. Oh yeah, also he was afraid of his daughter eating his food. Another good reason to kill her. Maybe he also ate her? No, we learn from the last page we find that he threw her body in the woods. Shouldn't he have eaten her since he abolished humanity long ago? Not so practical afterall, huh? Anyway, he kept her fingerbones as a symbol of sorts to his liberation. (Why those? Makes no sense? Yeah, but who cares!)
At some point after that he got out of his bunker, survived a little, felt the need to return, got controlled by the player and upon dying in the cellar of his bunker, right next to where his daughter died, despite still hearing her screams found a feeling of freedom and peace (2deep4u again). If I missed or misinterpreted any of the story please feel free to comment and tell me so.
6) The riddles were ridiculous. Just finding all the notes and reading them is enough. I understand they're the game's way of forcingguiding one through the story, but just making them that easy is a great waste of potential. The concept also fails as stated in 3).

I was happy there weren't any jumpscares though. Thanks a lot for that. Even though I got screamed at by the guy's daughter a little (ambient noise) I'm happy the designer didn't take that road trying to enhance his game by putting in random shockers. Working with suspense is often better than giving away too much.
